next.name: Knowledge of the Faculties of Persons

segments.pli: Aṅguttara Nikāya 6
segments.en: Numbered Discourses 6

segments.pli: 6. Mahāvagga
segments.en: 6. The Great Chapter

segments.pli: 61. Majjhesutta
segments.en: 61. In the Middle

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
segments.en: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several senior mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them,

segments.pli: “vuttamidaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā pārāyane metteyyapañhe:
segments.en: “Reverends, this was said by the Buddha in ‘The Way to the Beyond’, in ‘The Questions of Metteyya’:

segments.pli: ‘Yo ubhonte viditvāna,
segments.en: ‘The sage has known both ends,

segments.pli: majjhe mantā na lippati;
segments.en: and is not stuck in the middle.

segments.pli: Taṃ brūmi mahāpurisoti,
segments.en: He is a great man, I declare,

segments.pli: sodha sibbini maccagā’”ti.
segments.en: he has escaped the seamstress here.’

segments.pli: “Katamo nu kho, āvuso, eko anto, katamo dutiyo anto, kiṃ majjhe, kā sibbinī”ti?
segments.en: But what is one end? What’s the second end? What’s the middle? And who is the seamstress?”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “phasso kho, āvuso, eko anto, phassasamudayo dutiyo anto, phassanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “Contact, reverends, is one end. The origin of contact is the second end. The cessation of contact is the middle. And craving is the seamstress,

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
segments.en: for craving weaves one to rebirth in this or that state of existence.

segments.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (1)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “atītaṃ kho, āvuso, eko anto, anāgataṃ dutiyo anto, paccuppannaṃ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “The past, reverends, is one end. The future is the second end. The present is the middle. And craving is the seamstress …

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto, pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (2)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows … an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “sukhā, āvuso, vedanā eko anto, dukkhā vedanā dutiyo anto, adukkhamasukhā vedanā majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “Pleasant feeling, reverends, is one end. Painful feeling is the second end. Neutral feeling is the middle. And craving is the seamstress …

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto, pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (3)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows … an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “nāmaṃ kho, āvuso, eko anto, rūpaṃ dutiyo anto, viññāṇaṃ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “Name, reverends, is one end. Form is the second end. Consciousness is the middle. And craving is the seamstress …

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (4)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows … an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “cha kho, āvuso, ajjhattikāni āyatanāni eko anto, cha bāhirāni āyatanāni dutiyo anto, viññāṇaṃ majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “The six interior sense fields, reverends, are one end. The six exterior sense fields are the second end. Consciousness is the middle. And craving is the seamstress …

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (5)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows … an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “sakkāyo kho, āvuso, eko anto, sakkāyasamudayo dutiyo anto, sakkāyanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “Identity, reverends, is one end. The origin of identity is the second end. The cessation of identity is the middle. And craving is the seamstress,

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
segments.en: for craving weaves one to rebirth in this or that state of existence.

segments.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti. (6)
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu there bhikkhū etadavoca:
segments.en: When this was said, one of the mendicants said to the senior mendicants:

segments.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
segments.en: “Each of us has spoken from the heart.

segments.pli: Āyāmāvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocessāma.
segments.en: Come, reverends, let’s go to the Buddha, and inform him about this.

segments.pli: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā”ti. (7)
segments.en: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho therā bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” those senior mendicants replied.

segments.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
segments.en: Then those senior mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho therā bhikkhū yāvatako ahosi sabbeheva saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesuṃ.
segments.en: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed. They asked,

segments.pli: “Kassa nu kho, bhante, subhāsitan”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, who has spoken well?”

segments.pli: “Sabbesaṃ vo, bhikkhave, subhāsitaṃ pariyāyena, api ca yaṃ mayā sandhāya bhāsitaṃ pārāyane metteyyapañhe:
segments.en: “Mendicants, you’ve all spoken well in a way. However, this is what I was referring to in ‘The Way to the Beyond’, in ‘The Questions of Metteyya’ when I said:

segments.pli: ‘Yo ubhonte viditvāna,
segments.en: ‘The sage has known both ends,

segments.pli: majjhe mantā na lippati;
segments.en: and is not stuck in the middle.

segments.pli: Taṃ brūmi mahāpurisoti,
segments.en: He is a great man, I declare,

segments.pli: sodha sibbinimaccagā’ti.
segments.en: he has escaped the seamstress here.’

segments.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho therā bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “phasso kho, bhikkhave, eko anto, phassasamudayo dutiyo anto, phassanirodho majjhe, taṇhā sibbinī;
segments.en: “Contact, mendicants, is one end. The origin of contact is the second end. The cessation of contact is the middle. And craving is the seamstress,

segments.pli: taṇhā hi naṃ sibbati tassa tasseva bhavassa abhinibbattiyā.
segments.en: for craving weaves one to rebirth in this or that state of existence.

segments.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānāti, pariññeyyaṃ parijānāti, abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānanto pariññeyyaṃ parijānanto diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro hotī”ti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant directly knows what should be directly known and completely understands what should be completely understood. Knowing and understanding thus they make an end of suffering in this very life.”

segments.pli: Sattamaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: Several senior mendicants discuss the “Questions of Metteyya” from the Pārāyana (Snp 5.3). Each propose an interpretation, and they then ask the Buddha. He praises each reading, but gives his own intended meaning.
